Award.AwardTitle: Redox-switching and Topology Control in Metallosurfactant Precursors for Supramolecular Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Cl√°udio N. Verani at the Wayne State University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Division of Chemistry to conduct research on the use of metal-containing amphiphiles for redox-active supramolecular thin films. This interdisciplinary program seeks to merge redox-driven switching in transition-metal coordination complexes with molecular organization at surfaces, and focuses on three aims: (i) the development of redox-active amphiphiles and hydrophobes based on five-coordinate M(III)-complexes with electroactive ligands, (ii) the design of redox-active amphiphiles of discoid topology based on modular multimetallic cores, and (iii) the development of novel approaches to assemble extended modular Langmuir films at the air-water interface. These aims require a comprehensive and multidisciplinary knowledge in synthetic methodologies, electrochemical, spectroscopic, computational, isothermal compression, and microscopy methods.

This research is an effort to translate information learned from small transition metal complexes into useful systems that foster the development of new materials and devices. The educational component is based on a socio-cognitive approach and uses unifying topics such as soaps and simpler experiments to reach out for graduate students, middle school students, as well as kindergartners of the Detroit School System. In addition, this research provides multidisciplinary research training for undergraduates and graduate students in inorganic and materials chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2010 the NSF granted the investigation of the project “Redox-switching and Topology Control in Metallosurfactant Precursors for Supramolecular Films” (CHE-1012413). The Verani Group works on the development of molecular materials that may find applications in the fabrication of electronic components. This field is known as molecular electronics and requires a multidisciplinary approach that involves coordination and redox chemistry, and surface and interface phenomena. We are working on molecules that will be incorporated in devices for current rectification, an asymmetric flow of electricity similar to that observed in vacuum tubes and solid-state diodes. This control the mobility of current enables it to flow in one direction and prevents reversibility, and is fundamental to the conversion of alternating into direct current used in computers. We focus on the use of metal-containing species (coordination compounds) that are capable of response to an electric impulse (redox), AND can be organized and oriented in a solid film (interface phenomena) to develop soap like materials know as metallosurfactants. In order to tackle these problems an intimate knowledge of each of these aspects is necessary, and this information, then, needs to be merged in new compounds that will be used in more intricate devices.

Significant progress was made during the period of the grant: We learned that the nature of the metal ion and of the ligand protonation determine the redox and interfacial properties of metallosurfactants, we investigated the possibility of using clusters of four or more metal ions in a single metallosurfactant, we established methodology to study metallosurfactants, including archetypical and computational modelling,  and the introduction of cutting edge microscopy and spectroscopy methods.

One series of compounds was particularly fruitful; it involves five-coordinate iron(III) complexes with multiple phenolate groups and their electronic changes related to redox-triggered ground states. We characterized the electronic behavior of these compounds and developed nanodevices capable of current rectification. There are very few such devices described in the literature and ours is the first of a kind using metal ions. This is one small first step towards computers based on molecules. It might even seem uncertain to do research in such fundamental issues. However, sooner or later silicon-based computing will require alternatives, because current computers are incapable of solving non-binary and creative problems. This is also certainly out of mainstream computation, but so was the first computer —a massive behemoth called the ENIAC— back in 1946. And mere 68 years ago, the simple notion of a tablet pc or a smart phone would sound either absurd, or something from science fiction. Therefore, the most important challenge is not so much the question of whether this technology will soon become viable, but rather it is to understand that sooner or later molecule-based computing will become a reality.
